It was a false alarn as the Japs raided a field between
Chungking and Wahsien but Sharp had to fly for two hours before he could
come back and land.
That afternoon about five both Sharp and Leonard went
to Hankow and
took fifteen passengers each to Chengtu leaving Hankon about
Everything went well except that both pilots ran into snow and
ice going
the mountains near Chengtu and both of then did not make
time we had hoped.
Sharp who was leading got out of Henkow on his
second trip
just at day light but Leonard who was about twenty minutes
behind ran into an air raid over Fankow.
le saw the planes but as no raid
warning
had been given him he thought they were Chinese until be saw the
bombs
bursting on
the airport.
He then turned around and ran back to Ichang-
The air raid
alarn service in Hankow had been discontinued and evacuated.
After
he
got
to
Ichang I sent him word to return to Chungking.
He was delayed
in getting gas at Ichang as we keep no gas on the field there, so he did not
get back
to
Chungking until after twelve noon. He hed been flying almost
constantly since five oclock the afternoon before and had flown to Hongkong
and back the night
before that.
I sent him home and told him his flighte for
that night
were cancelled.
He protested he was alright and would be able to
fly but Idid not listen to him.
When the raid, which Leonard just missed cane over Hankow that
morning,
all of Leonardts passengers were at the field waiting for the plane.
raid cane they scraned in all directions.
Some hid in the drain
ditch around the field, some jumped into old bomb holes and sone ducked into
a dug-out nearby.
the last man
Mechanic Haynie who stopped to look after the passengers
to make the dug-out and the Japs were machine-gunning hin
One passenger, & high official in the Ministry of Railroads,
out after the raid was over, and he was told the plane would
took five hours to get him out and they had to back a car up
The weather got worse until it becane clearly impossible to fly
over the mountains
to Chengtu at night with any degree of
safety at ally so
I wired Hankow we would have only
one flight that night.
The plane would
after dark and leave in the morning
just at dawn for Chungking.
The replies
we got to that from lankow were really frantic.
I decided I
had better
that night and explain our problems to the Minister.
see Socony and I wanted to check up on the evacuation of our
The flight down was uneventful, the weather was bad and we flew
the way.
We had a bad leing condition with the temperature only
three degrees
above freezing,
If we had pulled up, as we would have to do
at night,
it might have been difficult.
We got to Ichang and out of the
just at dark and
on into Honkow a little after eight.
but interesting spectacle.
It was a
particularly dark
smal) lanterns and flash lights were allowed.
The field had
been heavily
bonbed recently and none of the holes were being filled up.
All over the field were gangs of coolies digging and we were told they were
I located
the nearest bomb hole and made a mental note of
Its bearing from the plane and I was all prepared to dive in it if necessary.
, PlOS
